page.title: 01HILLS TO S.W. OF ROTHESAY
page.content: The square is mainly open countryside. Dominnantly of rough grassland and heather. With some deciduous and coniferous woodland. There are seven farms, mainly dairy, with some sheep averaging 150 acres, mainly to the west. There are two large areas of open fresh water, the Dhe Loch and Loch Fad. Of approximately 10 acres and 70 acres respectively geologically the dominant feature is the highland boundary fault which runs through the south-east corner of the square. Loch Fad forms part of this fault. The ground rises from sea level in the west at the sandy beach of St. Ninians Bay, to the ridge of hills flanking the west shore of Loch Fad, averaging 400 ft. On the east side of this ridge is the rich deciduous woodland of Barmore. There is a rainbow trout farm on Loch Fad. In winter the farmland
